awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Adaptive Intelligence for Cyber-Physical Automotive Active Safety - System Design and Evaluation
awd_abstract_narration:
The automotive industry finds itself at a cross-roads. Current advances in MEMS sensor technology, the emergence of embedded control software, the rapid progress in computer technology, digital image processing, machine learning and control algorithms, along with an ever increasing investment in vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) technologies, are about to revolutionize the way we use vehicles and commute in everyday life. Automotive active safety systems, in particular, have been used with enormous success in the past 50 years and have helped keep traffic accidents in check. Still, more than 30,000 deaths and 2,000,000 injuries occur each year in the US alone, and many more worldwide. The impact of traffic accidents on the economy is estimated to be as high as $300B/yr in the US alone. Further improvement in terms of driving safety (and comfort) necessitates that the next generation of active safety systems are more proactive (as opposed to reactive) and can comprehend and interpret driver intent. Future active safety systems will have to account for the diversity of drivers' skills, the behavior of drivers in traffic, and the overall traffic conditions.

This research aims at improving the current capabilities of automotive active safety control systems (ASCS) by taking into account the interactions between the driver, the vehicle, the ASCS and the environment. Beyond solving a fundamental problem in automotive industry, this research will have ramifications in other cyber-physical domains, where humans manually control vehicles or equipment including: flying, operation of heavy machinery, mining, tele-robotics, and robotic medicine. Making autonomous/automated systems that feel and behave "naturally" to human operators is not always easy. As these systems and machines participate more in everyday interactions with humans, the need to make them operate in a predictable manner is more urgent than ever.

To achieve the goals of the proposed research, this project will use the estimation of the driver's cognitive state to adapt the ASCS accordingly, in order to achieve a seamless operation with the driver. Specifically, new methodologies will be developed to infer long-term and short-term behavior of drivers via the use of Bayesian networks and neuromorphic algorithms to estimate the driver's skills and current state of attention from eye movement data, together with dynamic motion cues obtained from steering and pedal inputs. This information will be injected into the ASCS operation in order to enhance its performance by taking advantage of recent results from the theory of adaptive and real-time, model-predictive optimal control. The correct level of autonomy and workload distribution between the driver and ASCS will ensure that no conflicts arise between the driver and the control system, and the safety and passenger comfort are not compromised. A comprehensive plan will be used to test and validate the developed theory by collecting measurements from several human subjects while operating a virtual reality-driving simulator.

por.por_cntn:
Current automotive active safety control systems (ASCS) are designed with a “one fits all” mentality. There is no customization that takes into consideration individual driver condition and driving skills. This practice leads to simple and robust designs, but it may sacrifice performance and driver acceptance. The goal of this research was to improve the current capabilities of automotive active safety control systems (ASCS) by considering the interactions between the driver, the vehicle, the ASCS, and the environment.


This project developed new algorithms for inferring long-term and short-term behavior of drivers via the use of Bayesian networks and neuromorphic algorithms to estimate the driver’s skills and current state of attention from eye movement data, together with dynamic motion cues obtained from steering and pedal inputs. Once the driver internal state is identified, this information is injected into the ASCS operation to enhance its performance. By taking advantage of recent results from the theory of adaptive and real-time systems, model predictive optimal control designs have been proposed that modify the ASCS in a predictable and safe manner for better safety and comfort. The correct level of autonomy and workload distribution between the driver and ASCS ensures that no conflicts will arise between the driver and the control system, and the safety and passenger comfort are not compromised.


As part of this project, we have also developed a driving simulator environment to test our algorithms using real-time human-in-the-loop driving experiments. We have tested a number of traffic scenarios in a virtual environment of the Georgia Tech campus and demonstrated the benefits of our approach.


Although automotive active safety systems have been used with enormous success in the past 50 years and have helped keep traffic accidents in check, further improvements in terms of driving safety (and comfort) necessitates that the next generation of active safety systems are more proactive (as opposed to reactive) and can comprehend and interpret driver intent. In this work we have used this idea, but we went one step further: we used the estimation of the driver's cognitive state to adapt the ASCS to achieve a seamless operation with the driver. The results of this research will have an immediate impact on the future design of car automation, as they will provide engineers and researchers with low level and higher-level controllers that adapt to the driver's style. 


Several students have been supported by this award. Among them, two students received their doctoral dissertation. Kazuhide Okamoto received his PhD degree with the dissertation “Optimal Covariance Steering: Theory and its Application to Autonomous Driving”. In his thesis, he developed a new theory for uncertainty mitigation and applied the theory to autonomous driving applications. Changxi You received his PhD degree with the dissertation “Autonomous Aggressive Driving: Theory and Experiments”. His thesis proposed new methods for modeling the driver and for developing driving techniques that mimic human drivers.

 Several (50+) undergraduate students were also involved in this project as part of a VIP team on “Active Safety for Autonomous and Semi-Autonomous Vehicles”. Several of these students were supported by an REU supplement or via Georgia Tech’s PURA undergraduate research program. The VIP program is an undergraduate education program by which students earn academic credit for their participation in design/discovery efforts that assist faculty and graduate students with research issues in their areas of expertise. The VIP teams are multidisciplinary (drawing students from all disciplines on campus); vertically-integrated (maintaining a mix of sophomores through PhD students each semester); and long-term (each undergraduate student may participate in a project for up to three years and each graduate student may participate for the duration of their graduate career). The students who participated in this VIP team designed and constructed several versions of small autonomous vehicles and they also helped with the development of a high-fidelity driving simulator that was used for the experimental testing of the theory.
